incense.wordExtraNote: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one to study
incense.sentence_1: When Herb bought football tickets for a game on the day of their wedding anniversary, Jill was incensed.

conundrum.sentence_1: Computers have helped solve some of the mathematical conundrums which have puzzled man for many centuries.

piquant.meaning_1: adjective: having an agreeably pungent taste
piquant.sentence_1: The chef, with a mere flick of the salt shaker, turned the bland tomato soup into a piquant meal.

emulate.meaning_1: verb: strive to equal or match, especially by imitating; compete with successfully
emulate.sentence_1: To really become fluent in a new language, emulate the speech patterns of people who speak the language.

evenhanded.sentence_1: Teachers often have trouble being evenhanded to all of their varied students.

irascible.sentence_1: If Arthur's dog is not fed adequately, he becomes highly irascible, even growling at his own shadow.

incumbent.meaning_1: adjective: necessary (for someone) as a duty or responsibility
incumbent.wordExtraNote: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one to study
incumbent.sentence_1: Middle managers at times make important decisions, but real responsibility for the financial well-being of the corporation is ultimately incumbent on the CEO.

presumptuous.sentence_1: Many felt that Barney was presumptuous in moving into the large office before the management even made any official announcement of his promotion.

foolhardy.meaning_1: adjective: marked by defiant disregard for danger or consequences
foolhardy.sentence_1: The police regularly face dangerous situations, so for a police officer not to wear his bullet-proof vest is foolhardy.

redress.meaning_1: noun: an act of making something right
redress.sentence_1: Barry's redress for forgetting his wife's birthday two years in a row was surprising her with a trip to Tahiti.

glean.meaning_1: verb: collect information bit by bit
glean.sentence_1: Herb has given us no formal statement about his background, but from various hints, I have gleaned that he grew up in difficult circumstances.

intermittent.meaning_1: adjective: stopping and starting at irregular intervals
intermittent.sentence_1: The intermittent thunder continued and the night was punctuated by cracks of lightning—a surreal sleepless night.

eccentric.meaning_1: adjective: highly unconventional or unusual (usually describes a person)
eccentric.sentence_1: Mozart was well-known for his eccentricities, often speaking words backward to confuse those around him.

tribulation.meaning_1: noun: something, especially an event, that causes difficulty and suffering
tribulation.sentence_1: As of 2013, nearly 1.5 million Syrians have fled their country hoping to escape the tribulations of a civil war tearing their country to pieces.

deride.meaning_1: verb: treat or speak of with contempt
deride.sentence_1: The nun derided the students for trying to sneak insects and worms into the classroom.

humdrum.sentence_1: Having grown up in a humdrum suburb, Jacob relished life in New York City after moving.

rile.meaning_1: verb: cause annoyance in; disturb, especially by minor irritations
rile.sentence_1: Dan is usually calm and balanced, but it takes only one intense glare from Sabrina to rile him.

antedate.sentence_1: Harry was so unknowledgable that he was unaware the Egyptian pharaohs antedated the American Revolution.

preempt.meaning_1: verb: take the place of or have precedence over
preempt.sentence_1: A governmental warning about an imminent terrorist attack would preempt ordinary network programming on television.

forthright.meaning_1: adjective: characterized by directness in manner or speech; without subtlety or evasion
forthright.sentence_1: I did not expect the insurance agent to give us any straight answers, but I was pleasantly surprised by how forthright he was.

cerebral.meaning_1: adjective: involving intelligence rather than emotions or instinct
cerebral.wordExtraNote: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one to study
cerebral.sentence_1: A cerebral analysis of most pop music finds it to be simple and childish, but that ignores the point--the music's effect on the listener.

profusion.meaning_1: noun: the property of being extremely abundant
profusion.sentence_1: When Maria reported that she had been visited by Jesus Christ and had proof, a profusion of reporters and journalists descended on the town.

fawn.meaning_1: verb: try to gain favor by extreme flattery
fawn.wordExtraNote: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one to study
fawn.sentence_1: The media fawned over the handsome new CEO, praising his impeccable sense of style instead of asking more pointed questions.

buttress.sentence_1: China's economy has been buttressed by a global demand for the electronic parts the country manufactures.

besmirch.meaning_1: verb: damage the good name and reputation of someone
besmirch.sentence_1: The prince's distasteful choice of words besmirched not only his own name, but the reputation of the entire royal family.

behoove.meaning_1: verb: to be one's duty or obligation
behoove.sentence_1: The teacher looked down at the student and said, "It would behoove you to be in class on time and complete your homework, so that you don't repeat freshman English for a third straight year."

belittle.meaning_1: verb: lessen the importance, dignity, or reputation of
belittle.sentence_1: A good teacher will never belittle his students, but will instead empower them.

implicate.sentence_2: The crime boss was implicated for a long list of crimes, ranging from murder to disturbing the peace.
implicate.meaning_2: verb: to indicate in wrongdoing, usually a crime
implicate.sentence_1: By saying that some of the guests were uncomfortable, the manager implicated to the hotel staff that it needed to be more diligent.

cavalier.meaning_1: adjective: given to haughty disregard of others
cavalier.sentence_1: Percy dismissed the issue with a cavalier wave of his hand.

lethargic.sentence_1: Nothing can make a person more lethargic than a big turkey dinner.

rakish.meaning_1: adjective: marked by a carefree unconventionality or disreputableness
rakish.sentence_1: As soon as he arrived in the city, the rakish young man bought some drugs and headed straight for the seedy parts of town.

coalesce.meaning_1: verb: fuse or cause to grow together
coalesce.sentence_1: Over time, the various tribes coalesced into a single common culture with one universal language.

melancholy.sentence_1: Hamlet is a figure of tremendous melancholy: he doesn't have a truly cheerful scene throughout the entire play.

insipid.sentence_1: The movie director was known for hiring beautiful actors in order to deflect attention away from the insipid scripts he would typically use.

docile.meaning_1: adjective: easily handled or managed; willing to be taught or led or supervised or directed
docile.sentence_1: Barnyard animals are considerably more docile than the wild animals.

precarious.sentence_1: People smoke to relax and forget their cares, but ironically, in terms of health risks, smoking is far more precarious than either mountain-climbing or skydiving.

avert.sentence_2: The struggling video game company put all of its finances into one final, desperate project to avert bankruptcy.
avert.sentence_1: Afraid to see the aftermath of the car crash, I averted my eyes as we drove by.

uncanny.meaning_1: adjective: suggesting the operation of supernatural influences; surpassing the ordinary or normal
uncanny.sentence_1: Reggie has an uncanny ability to connect with animals: feral cats will readily approach him, and sometimes even wild birds will land on his finger.

ascribe.sentence_1: History ascribes The Odyssey and The Iliad to Homer, but scholars now debate whether he was a historical figure or a fictitious name.

clemency.meaning_1: noun: leniency and compassion shown toward offenders by a person or agency charged with administering justice
clemency.sentence_1: In the final moments of the trial, during his closing speech, Phillips was nearly begging the judge for clemency.

prevail.sentence_2: Before the cricket match, Australia was heavily favored, but India prevailed.
prevail.sentence_1: During the labor negotiations, an air of hostility prevailed in the office.
prevail.meaning_1: verb: be widespread in a particular area at a particular time; be current:

wanton.meaning_1: adjective: without check or limitation; showing no moral restraints to one's anger, desire, or appetites
wanton.sentence_1: Due to wanton behavior and crude language, the drunk man was thrown out of the bar and asked to never return.

delegate.meaning_1: verb: give an assignment to (a person)
delegate.wordExtraNote: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one to study
delegate.sentence_1: Since the senior manager had to go on many international business trips, she was forced to delegate many of her responsibilities to two lower-level managers.

industrious.meaning_1: adjective: characterized by hard work and perseverance
industrious.sentence_1: Pete was an industrious student, completing every assignment thoroughly and on time.

analogous.meaning_1: adjective: similar in some respects but otherwise different
analogous.sentence_1: In many ways, the Internet's transformative effect on society has been analogous to that of the printing press.

begrudge.sentence_2: We never begrudge money spent on ourselves.
begrudge.sentence_1: Sitting all alone in his room, Harvey begrudged the happiness of the other children playing outside his window.
begrudge.meaning_1: verb: to envy someone for possessing or enjoying something

cohesive.meaning_1: adjective: well integrated, forming a united whole
cohesive.sentence_1: A well-written, cohesive essay will keep on topic at all times, never losing sight of the main argument.

veneer.meaning_1: noun: covering consisting of a thin superficial layer that hides the underlying substance
veneer.sentence_1: Mark Twain referred to the Victorian Period in America as the "Gilded Age", implying the ample moral corruption that lay beneath a mere veneer of respectability.

consecrate.meaning_1: verb: to make holy or set apart for a high purpose
consecrate.sentence_1: At the church of Notre Dame in France, the new High Altar was consecrated in 1182.

finagle.meaning_1: verb: achieve something by means of trickery or devious methods
finagle.sentence_1: Steven was able to finagle one of the last seats on the train by convincing the conductor that his torn stub was actually a valid ticket.
